maml:description.maml:para: Adds a back-end address pool to an application gateway.

The Add-AzureRmApplicationGatewayBackendAddressPool cmdlet adds a back-end address pool to an application gateway. A back-end address can be specified using an IP address, a fully-qualified domain name (FQDN) or IP configuration IDs.
Specifies the application gateway to which this cmdlet adds a back-end address pool.
Specifies the name of the back-end server pool that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies a list of back-end server IP configuration IDs that this cmdlet adds as a back-end server pool.
Specifies the application gateway to which this cmdlet adds a back-end address pool.
Specifies the name of the back-end server pool that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies a list of back-end IP addresses which this cmdlet adds as a back-end server pool.
Specifies the application gateway to which this cmdlet adds a back-end address pool.
Specifies the name of the back-end server pool that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies a list of backend FQDNs which this cmdlet adds as a back-end server pool.
Specifies the application gateway to which this cmdlet adds a back-end address pool.
Specifies the name of the back-end server pool that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies a list of back-end server IP configuration IDs that this cmdlet adds as a back-end server pool.
Specifies a list of back-end IP addresses which this cmdlet adds as a back-end server pool.
Specifies a list of backend FQDNs which this cmdlet adds as a back-end server pool.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
System.String

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azurerm, arm, resource, management, manager, network, networking

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Adding a backend address pool by using a backend server FQDN --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $AppGw = Get-AzureRmApplicationGateway -Name "ApplicationGateway01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Add-AzureRmApplicationGatewayBackendAddressPool -ApplicationGateway $AppGw -Name "Pool02" -BackendFqdns "contoso1.com", " contoso1.com"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the application gateway named ApplicationGateway01 in the resource group named ResourceGroup01, and stores it in the $AppGw variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Adding a backend address pool by using backend server IP addresses --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$AppGw = Get-AzureRmApplicationGateway -Name "ApplicationGateway01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Add -AzureApplicationGatewayBackendAddressPool -ApplicationGateway $ AppGw -Name "Pool02" -BackendIPAddresses "10.10.10.10", "10.10.10.11"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the application gateway named ApplicationGateway01 in the resource group named ResourceGroup01, and stores it in the $AppGw variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Setting a backend address pool by using the ID of the backend server’s IP address --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Nic01 = Get-AzureRmNetworkInterface -Name "Nic01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $Nic02 = Get-AzureRmNetworkInterface -Name "Nic02" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Get-AzureRmApplicationGateway -Name "ApplicationGateway01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Add-AzureRmApplicationGatewayBackendAddressPool -ApplicationGateway $ AppGw -Name "Pool02" -BackendIPConfigurationIds $nic01.Properties.IpConfigurations[0].Id, $nic02.Properties.IpConfiguration[0].Id

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a network interface object named Nic01 that belongs to the resource group named ResourceGroup01, and stores it in the $Nic01 variable.
The forth command uses the back-end IP configuration IDs from $Nic01 and $Nic02 to add the back-end address pool of the application gateway stored in $AppGw.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds back-end HTTP settings to an application gateway.
The Add-AzureRmApplicationGatewayBackendHttpSettings cmdlet adds back-end HTTP settings to an application gateway.
Back-end HTTP settings are applied to all back-end servers in the pool.
Specifies the name of the back-end HTTP settings which this cmdlet adds.
Specifies the port of the back-end server pool.
Specifies the protocol for communication between application gateway and back-end servers.
Specifies whether cookie-based affinity should be enabled or disabled for the backend server pool. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Disabled, Enabled.
The Add-AzureRmApplicationGatewayBackendHttpSettings cmdlet adds back-end HTTP settings to an application gateway.
Back-end HTTP settings are applied to all back-end servers in the pool.

Specifies the port of the back-end server pool.
Specifies the protocol for communication between application gateway and back-end servers.
Specifies whether cookie-based affinity should be enabled or disabled for the backend server pool. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Disabled, Enabled.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a front-end IP configuration to an application gateway.

The Add-AzureRmApplicationGatewayFrontendIPConfig cmdlet adds a front-end IP configuration to an application gateway. An application gateway supports two types of front-end IP configurations. -- Public IP addresses -- Private IP addresses using internal load-balancing (ILB)
An application gateway can have at most one public IP and one private IP. Add the public IP address and private IP address as separate front-end IPs.
Specifies the application gateway to which this cmdlet adds a front-end IP configuration.
Specifies the name of the front-end IP configuration to add.
Specifies the private IP address to add as a front-end IP for the application gateway. If specified, this IP is statically allocated from the subnet.

Specifies the subnet which this cmdlet adds as front-end IP configuration. If you specify this parameter, it implies that the application gateway supports a private IP based-configuration. If the PrivateIPAddress parameter is specified, it should belong to this subnet. If PrivateIPAddress is not specified, one of the IP addresses from this subnet is dynamically picked up as the front-end IP address of the application gateway.
Specifies the public IP address which this cmdlet adds as a front-end IP address for the application gateway.
Specifies the application gateway to which this cmdlet adds a front-end IP configuration.
Specifies the name of the front-end IP configuration to add.
Specifies the private IP address to add as a front-end IP for the application gateway. If specified, this IP is statically allocated from the subnet.

Specifies the subnet ID which this cmdlet adds as the front-end IP configuration. Passing subnet implies private IP. If the PrivateIPAddresss parameter is specified, it should belong to this subnet. Otherwise, one of the IP from this subnet is dynamically picked up as the front-end IP of the application gateway.
Specifies the ID of the public IP address which this cmdlet adds as a front-end IP address for the application gateway.
Specifies the application gateway to which this cmdlet adds a front-end IP configuration.
Specifies the name of the front-end IP configuration to add.
Specifies the private IP address to add as a front-end IP for the application gateway. If specified, this IP is statically allocated from the subnet.

Specifies the subnet which this cmdlet adds as front-end IP configuration. If you specify this parameter, it implies that the application gateway supports a private IP based-configuration. If the PrivateIPAddress parameter is specified, it should belong to this subnet. If PrivateIPAddress is not specified, one of the IP addresses from this subnet is dynamically picked up as the front-end IP address of the application gateway.
Specifies the public IP address which this cmdlet adds as a front-end IP address for the application gateway.

Specifies the subnet ID which this cmdlet adds as the front-end IP configuration. Passing subnet implies private IP. If the PrivateIPAddresss parameter is specified, it should belong to this subnet. Otherwise, one of the IP from this subnet is dynamically picked up as the front-end IP of the application gateway.
Specifies the ID of the public IP address which this cmdlet adds as a front-end IP address for the application gateway.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azurerm, arm, resource, management, manager, network, networking

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Add a public IP as the frontend IP address --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $PublicIp = New-AzureRmPublicIpAddress -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" -Name "PublicIp01" -location "West US" -AllocationMethod Dynamic PS C:\> $AppGw = Get-AzureRmApplicationGateway -Name "ApplicationGateway01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Add-AzureRmApplicationGatewayFrontendIPConfig -ApplicationGateway $AppGw -Name "FrontEndIp01" –PublicIPAddress $PublicIp

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command creates a public IP address object and stores it in the $PublicIp variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Add a static private IP as the frontend IP address --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$VNet = Get-AzureRmvirtualNetwork -Name "VNet01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $Subnet = Get-AzureRmVirtualNetworkSubnetConfig -Name "Subnet01" -VirtualNetwork $VNet PS C:\> $AppGw = Get-AzureRmApplicationGateway -Name "ApplicationGateway01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Add-AzureRmApplicationGatewayFrontendIPConfig -ApplicationGateway $AppGw -Name "FrontendIP02" -Subnet $Subnet -PrivateIPAddress 10.0.1.1

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a virtual network named VNet01 that belongs to the resource group named ResourceGroup01, and stores it in the $VNet variable.
The fourth command adds a front-end IP configuration named FrontendIP02 using $Subnet from the second command and the private IP address 10.0.1.1.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Add a dynamic private IP as the frontend IP address --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$VNet = Get-AzureRmvirtualNetwork -Name "VNet01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $Subnet = Get-AzureRmVirtualNetworkSubnetConfig -Name "Subnet01" -VirtualNetwork $VNet PS C:\> $AppGw = Get-AzureRmApplicationGateway -Name "ApplicationGateway01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Add-AzureRmApplicationGatewayFrontendIPConfig -ApplicationGateway $AppGw -Name "FrontendIP02" -Subnet $Subnet

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a virtual network named VNet01 that belongs to the resource group named ResourceGroup01, and stores it in the $VNet variable.
The fourth command adds a front-end IP configuration named FrontendIP02 using $Subnet from the second command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Add a HTTP listener --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$AppGw = Get-AzureRmApplicationGateway -Name "ApplicationGateway01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $Appgw = Add-AzureRmApplicationGatewayHttpListener -ApplicationGateway $AppGw -Name "listener01" -Protocol "Http" -FrontendIpConfiguration $FIP01 -FrontendPort $FP01

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the application gateway and stores it in the $AppGw variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Add a HTTPS listener with SSL --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$AppGw = Get-AzureRmApplicationGateway -Name "ApplicationGateway01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Add-AzureRmApplicationGatewayHttpListener -ApplicationGateway $AppGw -Name "Listener01" -Protocol "Https" -FrontendIpConfiguration $FIP01 -FrontendPort $FP01 – SslCertificate $SSLCert01

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 Add a frontend IP configuration with a dynamic IP address --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Subnet = Get-AzureRmVirtualNetwork -Name "myVnet" -ResourceGroupName "myRg" | Get-AzureRmVirtualNetworkSubnetConfig -Name "mysubnet" PS C:\> Get-AzureRmLoadBalancer -Name "myLB" -ResourceGroupName "NrpTest" | Add-AzureRmLoadBalancerFrontendIpConfig -Name "frontendName" -Subnet $Subnet | Set-AzureRmLoadBalancer

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a front-end IP configuration to the load balancer with a dynamic private IP address from the specified subnet.

command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Subnet = Get-AzureRmVirtualNetwork -Name "myVnet" -ResourceGroupName "myRg" | Get-AzureRmVirtualNetworkSubnetConfig -Name "mysubnet" PS C:\> Get-AzureRmLoadBalancer -Name "myLB" -ResourceGroupName "NrpTest" | Add-AzureRmLoadBalancerFrontendIpConfig -Name "frontendName" -Subnet $Subnet -PrivateIpAddress "10.0.1.6" | Set-AzureRmLoadBalancer

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a front-end IP configuration to the load balancer with a public IP address.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azurerm, arm, resource, management, manager, network, networking

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Add an inbound NAT rule configuration to a load balancer --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Lb = Get-AzureRmLoadBalancer -Name "myLb" -ResourceGroupName "myRg" PS C:\> $Lb | Add-AzureRmLoadBalancerInboundNatRuleConfig -Name "natRule" -FrontendIPConfiguration$lb.Properties.FrontendIPConfigurations[0] -BackendIpConfiguration $Nic.Properties.IpConfigurations[0] -Protocol "Tcp" -FrontendPort 3350 -BackendPort 3350 -IdleTimeoutInSeconds 17 -EnableFloatingIP | Set-AzureRmLoadBalancer

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the load balancer named myLb, and then stores it in the $Lb variable.

command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureRmLoadBalancer -Name "myLb" -ResourceGroupName "myRg" | Add-AzureRmLoadBalancerProbeConfig -Name "probeName" -RequestPath healthcheck2.aspx -Protocol http -Port 81 -IntervalInSeconds 16 -ProbeCount 3 | Set-AzureRmLoadBalancer

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 Add a rule configuration to a load balancer --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$LoadBalancer = Get-AzureRmLoadBalancer -Name "MyLoadBalancer" -ResourceGroupName "MyResourceGroup" PS C:\> $LoadBalancer | Add-AzureRmLoadBalancerRuleConfig -Name "LbRuleConfig" -FrontendIPConfiguration $LoadBalancer.Properties.FrontendIPConfigurations[0] -BackendAddressPool $LoadBalancer.Properties.BackendAddressPools[0] -Probe $LoadBalancer.Properties.Probes[0] -Protocol "Tcp" -FrontendPort 80 -BackendPort 80 -IdleTimeoutInSeconds 15 -EnableFloatingIP | Set-AzureRmLoadBalancer

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the load balancer named MyLoadBalancer, and then stores it in the $LoadBalancer variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a network security rule configuration to a network security group.
The Add-AzureRmNetworkSecurityRuleConfig cmdlet adds a network security rule configuration to an Azure network security group.
Specifies the name of a network security rule configuration.
Specifies a NetworkSecurityGroup object. This cmdlet adds a network security rule configuration to the object that this parameter specifies.
Specifies a description of a network security rule configuration.
Specifies the network protocol that a rule configuration applies to. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Tcp -- Udp -- Wildcard character (*) to match both
Specifies a source port or range. This value is expressed as an integer, as a range between 0 and 65535, or as a wildcard character (*) to match any source port.
Specifies a destination port or range. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- An integer -- A range of integers between 0 and 65535 -- A wildcard character (*) to match any port
Specifies a source address prefix. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- A CIDR -- A source IP range -- A wildcard character (*) to match any IP address.
You can also use tags such as VirtualNetwork, AzureLoadBalancer and Internet.
Specifies a destination address prefix. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- A Classless Interdomain Routing (CIDR) address -- A destination IP address range -- A wildcard character (*) to match any IP address
You can use tags such as VirtualNetwork, AzureLoadBalancer, and Internet.
Specifies whether network traffic is allowed or denied. The acceptable values for this parameter are:Allow and Deny.
Specifies the priority of a rule configuration. The acceptable values for this parameter are:An integer between 100 and 4096.
The priority number must be unique for each rule in the collection. The lower the priority number, the higher the priority of the rule.
Specifies whether a rule is evaluated on incoming or outgoing traffic. The acceptable values for this parameter are:Inbound and Outbound.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a route to a route table.
The Add-AzureRmRouteConfig cmdlet adds a route to an Azure route table.
Specifies a name of the route to add to the route table.
Specifies the route table to which this cmdlet adds a route.
Specifies the destination, in Classless Interdomain Routing (CIDR) format, to which the route applies.
Specifies how this route forwards packets. Valid values are:

-- Internet. The default Internet gateway provided by Azure. -- None. If you specify this value, the route does not forward packets. -- VirtualAppliance. A virtual appliance that you add to your Azure virtual network. -- VirtualNetworkGateway. An Azure server-to-server virtual private network gateway. -- VnetLocal. The local virtual network. If you have two subnets, 10.1.0.0/16 and 10.2.0.0/16 in the same virtual network, select a value of VnetLocal for each subnet to forward to the other subnet.

Specifies the IP address of a virtual appliance that you add to your Azure virtual network. This route forwards packets to that address. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of VirtualAppliance for the NextHopType parameter.
Specifies a name of the route to add to the route table.
Specifies the route table to which this cmdlet adds a route.
Specifies the destination, in Classless Interdomain Routing (CIDR) format, to which the route applies.
Specifies how this route forwards packets. Valid values are:

-- Internet. The default Internet gateway provided by Azure. -- None. If you specify this value, the route does not forward packets. -- VirtualAppliance. A virtual appliance that you add to your Azure virtual network. -- VirtualNetworkGateway. An Azure server-to-server virtual private network gateway. -- VnetLocal. The local virtual network. If you have two subnets, 10.1.0.0/16 and 10.2.0.0/16 in the same virtual network, select a value of VnetLocal for each subnet to forward to the other subnet.

Specifies the IP address of a virtual appliance that you add to your Azure virtual network. This route forwards packets to that address. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of VirtualAppliance for the NextHopType parameter.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azurerm, arm, resource, management, manager, network, networking

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Add a route to a route table --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$RouteTable = Get-AzureRmRouteTable -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup11" -Name "routetable01" PS C:\> Add-AzureRmRouteConfig -Name "route13" -AddressPrefix 10.3.0.0/16 -NextHopType VnetLocal -RouteTable $RouteTable

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a route table named routetable01 by using the Get-AzureRmRouteTable cmdlet. The command stores the table in the $RouteTable variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Add a route to a route table by using the pipeline --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureRmRouteTable -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup11" -Name "routetable01" | Add-AzureRmRouteConfig -Name "route02" -AddressPrefix 10.2.0.0/16 -NextHopType VnetLocal | Set-AzureRmRouteTable Name : routetable01 ResourceGroupName : ResourceGroup11 Location : eastus Id : /subscriptions/xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx/resourceGroups/ResourceGroup11/providers/Microsoft.Networ k/routeTables/routetable01 Etag : W/"f13e1bc8-d41f-44d0-882d-b8b5a1134f59" ProvisioningState : Succeeded Tags : Routes : [ { "Name": "route07", "Etag": "W/\"f13e1bc8-d41f-44d0-882d-b8b5a1134f59\"", "Id": "/subscriptions/xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx/resourceGroups/ResourceGroup11/providers/Micro soft.Network/routeTables/routetable01/routes/route07", "AddressPrefix": "10.1.0.0/16", "NextHopType": "VnetLocal", "NextHopIpAddress": null, "ProvisioningState": "Succeeded" }, { "Name": "route02", "Etag": "W/\"f13e1bc8-d41f-44d0-882d-b8b5a1134f59\"", "Id": "/subscriptions/xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx/resourceGroups/ResourceGroup11/providers/Micro soft.Network/routeTables/routetable01/routes/route02", "AddressPrefix": "10.2.0.0/16", "NextHopType": "VnetLocal", "NextHopIpAddress": null, "ProvisioningState": "Succeeded" }, { "Name": "route13", "Etag": null, "Id": null, "AddressPrefix": "10.3.0.0/16", "NextHopType": "VnetLocal", "NextHopIpAddress": null, "ProvisioningState": null } ] Subnets : []

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the route table named routetable01 by using Get-AzureRmRouteTable. The command passes that table to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates an application gateway.
The New-AzureRmApplicationGateway cmdlet creates an Azure application gateway.
An application gateway requires the following:

-- A resource group. -- A virtual network. -- A back-end server pool, containing the IP addresses of the back-end servers. -- Back-end server pool settings. Each pool has settings such as port, protocol and cookie-based affinity, that are applied to all servers within the pool. -- Front-end IP addresses, which are the IP addresses opened on the application gateway. A front-end IP address can be a public IP address or an internal IP address. -- Front-end ports, which are the public ports opened on the application gateway. Traffic that hits these ports is redirected to the back-end servers. -- A request routing rule that binds the listener and the back-end server pool. The rule defines which back-end server pool the traffic should be directed to when it hits a particular listener. A listener has a front-end port, front-end IP address, protocol (http or https) and Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) certificate name (if configuring SSL offload).
Specifies the name of application gateway.
Specifies the name of the resource group in which to create the application gateway.
Specifies the region in which to create the application gateway.
Specifies the stock keeping unit (SKU) of the application gateway.
Specifies a list of IP configurations for the application gateway.
Specifies the list of Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) certificates for the application gateway.
Specifies a list of front-end IP configurations for the application gateway.
Specifies a list of front-end ports for the application gateway.
Specifies the list of back-end address pools for the application gateway.
Specifies the list of back-end HTTP settings for the application gateway.
Specifies a list of HTTP listeners for the application gateway.
Specifies a list of request routing rules for the application gateway.
Specifies the dictionary of tags associated with the application gateway.
Forces the creation of the application gateway even if an application gateway with the same name already exists.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a front-end IP configuration for an application gateway.
The New-AzureRmApplicationGatewayFrontendIPConfig cmdlet creates a front-end IP configuraton for an Azure application gateway. An application gateway supports two types of front-end IP configuration:
-- Public IP addresses -- Private IP addresses using internal load balancing (ILB).
An application gateway can have at most one public IP address and one private IP address. The public IP address and private IP address should be added separately as front-end IP addresses.
Specifies the name of the front-end IP configuration that this cmdlet creates.

Specifies the private IP address which this cmdlet associates with the front-end IP address of the application gateway. This can be specified only if a subnet is specified. This IP is statically allocated from the subnet.

Specifies the subnet object which this cmdlet associates with the front-end IP address of the application gateway. If you specify this parameter, it implies that the gateway uses a private IP address. If PrivateIPAddresss is specified, it should belong to the subnet specified by this parameter. If PrivateIPAddress is not specified, one of the IP addresses from this subnet is dynamically picked up as the front-end IP address of the application gateway.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Create a frontend IP configuration using a public IP resource object --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $ PublicIP = New-AzureRmPublicIpAddress -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" -Name "PublicIP01" -location "West US" -AllocationMethod Dynamic PS C:\> $FrontEnd = New-AzureRmApplicationGatewayFrontendIPConfig -Name "FrontEndIP01" –PublicIPAddress $PublicIP

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command creates a public IP resource object and stores it in the $PublicIP variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Create a static private IP as the frontend IP address --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$VNet = Get-AzureRmvirtualNetwork -Name "VNet01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $Subnet = Get-AzureRmVirtualNetworkSubnetConfig -Name "Subnet01" -VirtualNetwork $VNet PS C:\> $FrontEnd = New-AzureRmApplicationGatewayFrontendIPConfig -ApplicationGateway -Name "FrontendIP02" -Subnet $Subnet -PrivateIPAddress 10.0.1.1

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a virtual network named VNet01 that belongs to the resource group named ResourceGroup01, and stores it in the $VNet variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Create a dynamic private IP as the frontend IP address --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$VNet = Get-AzureRmvirtualNetwork -Name "VNet01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $Subnet = Get-AzureRmVirtualNetworkSubnetConfig -Name "Subnet01" -VirtualNetwork $VNet PS C:\> $FrontEnd = New-AzureRmApplicationGatewayFrontendIPConfig -ApplicationGateway -Name "FrontendIP03" -Subnet $Subnet

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a virtual network named VNet01 that belongs to the resource group named ResourceGroup01, and stores it in the $VNet variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a route for a route table.
The New-AzureRmRouteConfig cmdlet creates a route for an Azure route table.
Specifies a name for the route.
Specifies the destination, in Classless Interdomain Routing (CIDR) format, to which the route applies.
Specifies how this route forwards packets. Valid values are:

-- Internet. The default Internet gateway provided by Azure. -- None. If you specify this value, the route does not forward packets. -- VirtualAppliance. A virtual appliance that you add to your Azure virtual network. -- VirtualNetworkGateway. An Azure server-to-server virtual private network gateway. -- VnetLocal. The local virtual network. If you have two subnets, 10.1.0.0/16 and 10.2.0.0/16 in the same virtual network, select a value of VnetLocal for each subnet to forward to the other subnet.

Specifies the IP address of a virtual appliance that you add to your Azure virtual network. This route forwards packets to that address. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of VirtualAppliance for the NextHopType parameter.
Specifies a name for the route.
Specifies the destination, in Classless Interdomain Routing (CIDR) format, to which the route applies.
Specifies how this route forwards packets. Valid values are:

-- Internet. The default Internet gateway provided by Azure. -- None. If you specify this value, the route does not forward packets. -- VirtualAppliance. A virtual appliance that you add to your Azure virtual network. -- VirtualNetworkGateway. An Azure server-to-server virtual private network gateway. -- VnetLocal. The local virtual network. If you have two subnets, 10.1.0.0/16 and 10.2.0.0/16 in the same virtual network, select a value of VnetLocal for each subnet to forward to the other subnet.

Specifies the IP address of a virtual appliance that you add to your Azure virtual network. This route forwards packets to that address. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of VirtualAppliance for the NextHopType parameter.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Route = New-AzureRmRouteConfig -Name "route07" -AddressPrefix 10.1.0.0/16 -NextHopType VnetLocal PS C:\> $Route Name : route07 Id : Etag : ProvisioningState : AddressPrefix : 10.1.0.0/16 NextHopType : VnetLocal NextHopIpAddress :

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command creates a route named route07, and then stores it in the $Route variable. This route forwards packets to the local virtual network.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates a back-end address pool for an application gateway.

The Set-AzureRmApplicationGatewayBackendAddressPool cmdlet updates a back-end address pool for an Azure application gateway. Back-end addresses can be specified as IP addresses, fully-qualified domain names (FQDN) or IP configurations IDs.
Specifies the application gateway with which this cmdlet associates the back-end address pool.
Specifies the name of the back-end address pool. This back-end address pool must exist in the application gateway.
Specifies a list of back-end IP configuration IDs to use for the back-end server pool.

Specifies a list of back-end IP configuration IDs to use for the back-end server pool.

Specifies a list of back-end FQDNs to use as a back-end server pool.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azurerm, arm, resource, management, manager, network, networking

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Setting a backend address pool by using FQDNs --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$AppGw = Get-AzureRmApplicationGateway -Name "ApplicationGateway01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Set-AzureRmApplicationGatewayBackendAddressPool -ApplicationGateway $ AppGw -Name "Pool02" -BackendFqdns "contoso1.com", "contoso2.com"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the application gateway named ApplicationGateway01 in the resource group named ResourceGroup01, and stores it in the $AppGw variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Setting a backend address pool by using backend server IP addresses --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$AppGw = Get-AzureRmApplicationGateway -Name "ApplicationGateway01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Set-AzureRmApplicationGatewayBackendAddressPool -ApplicationGateway $ AppGw -Name "Pool02" -BackendIPAddresses "10.10.10.10", "10.10.10.11"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The second command gets the application gateway named ApplicationGateway01 in the resource group named ResourceGroup01, and stores it in the $AppGw variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Setting a backend address pool by using the ID of the backend server’s IP address --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Nic01 = Get-AzureRmNetworkInterface -Name "Nic01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $Nic02 = Get-AzureRmNetworkInterface -Name "Nic02" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Get-AzureRmApplicationGateway -Name "ApplicationGateway01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Set-AzureRmApplicationGatewayBackendAddressPool -ApplicationGateway $ AppGw -Name "Pool02" -BackendIPConfigurationIds $nic01.Properties.IpConfigurations[0].Id, $nic02.Properties.IpConfiguration[0].Id

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a network interface object named Nic01 that belongs to the resource group named ResourceGroup01, and stores it in the $Nic01 variable.
The forth command uses the back-end IP configuration IDs from $Nic01 and $Nic02 to update the back-end address pool of the application gateway in $AppGw.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies a front-end IP address configuration.
The Set-AzureRmApplicationGatewayFrontendIPConfig cmdlet updates a front-end IP configuration.
An application gateway supports two types of front-end IP addresses: -- Public IP addresses -- Private IP addresses for which the configuration uses Internal Load Balancing (ILB)
An application gateway can have at most one public IP address and one private IP address. A public IP address and a private IP address should be added separately as front-end IP addresses.
Specifies an application gateway object in which to modify the front-end IP configuration.
Specifies the name of the front-end IP configuration to modify.
Specifies the private IP address. If specified, this IP is statically allocated from the subnet.

Specifies the subnet that the application gateway uses. Specify this parameter if the gateway uses a private IP address. If PrivateIPAddress is specified, it should belong to this subnet. If PrivateIPAddress is not specified, one of the IP addresses from this subnet is dynamically picked up as the fron-tend IP address of the application gateway.
Specifies the public IP address.
Specifies an application gateway object in which to modify the front-end IP configuration.
Specifies the name of the front-end IP configuration to modify.
Specifies the private IP address. If specified, this IP is statically allocated from the subnet.

Specifies the subnet ID. Specify this parameter if the gateway uses a private IP address. If PrivateIPAddress is specified, it should belong to this subnet. If PrivateIPAddress is not specified, one of the IP addresses from this subnet is dynamically picked up as the front-end IP address of the application gateway.
Specifies the ID of the public IP address.
Specifies an application gateway object in which to modify the front-end IP configuration.
Specifies the name of the front-end IP configuration to modify.
Specifies the private IP address. If specified, this IP is statically allocated from the subnet.

Specifies the subnet that the application gateway uses. Specify this parameter if the gateway uses a private IP address. If PrivateIPAddress is specified, it should belong to this subnet. If PrivateIPAddress is not specified, one of the IP addresses from this subnet is dynamically picked up as the fron-tend IP address of the application gateway.
Specifies the public IP address.

Specifies the subnet ID. Specify this parameter if the gateway uses a private IP address. If PrivateIPAddress is specified, it should belong to this subnet. If PrivateIPAddress is not specified, one of the IP addresses from this subnet is dynamically picked up as the front-end IP address of the application gateway.
Specifies the ID of the public IP address.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azurerm, arm, resource, management, manager, network, networking

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Set a public IP as frontend IP of an application gateway --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $PublicIp = New-AzureRmPublicIpAddress -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" -Name "PublicIp01" -location "West US" -AllocationMethod Dynamic PS C:\> $AppGw = Get-AzureRmApplicationGateway -Name "ApplicationGateway01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Set-AzureRmApplicationGatewayFrontendIPConfig -ApplicationGateway $AppGw -Name "FrontEndIp01" –PublicIPAddress $PublicIp

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command creates a public IP address object and stores it in the $PublicIp variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Set a static private IP as the frontend IP of an application gateway --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$VNet = Get-AzureRmvirtualNetwork -Name "VNet01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $Subnet = Get-AzureRmVirtualNetworkSubnetConfig -Name "Subnet01" -VirtualNetwork $VNet PS C:\> $AppGw = Get-AzureRmApplicationGateway -Name "ApplicationGateway01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Set-AzureRmApplicationGatewayFrontendIPConfig -ApplicationGateway $AppGw -Name "FrontendIP02" -Subnet $Subnet -PrivateIPAddress 10.0.1.1

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a virtual network named VNet01 that belongs to the resource group named ResourceGroup01, and stores it in the $VNet variable.
The fourth command adds a front-end IP configuration named FrontendIP02 using $Subnet from the second command and the private IP address 10.0.1.1.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- 1: Set a dynamic private IP as the frontend IP of an application gateway --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$VNet = Get-AzureRmvirtualNetwork -Name "VNet01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $Subnet = Get-AzureRmVirtualNetworkSubnetConfig -Name "Subnet01" -VirtualNetwork $VNet PS C:\> $AppGw = Get-AzureRmApplicationGateway -Name "ApplicationGateway01" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" PS C:\> $AppGw = Set-AzureRmApplicationGatewayFrontendIPConfig -ApplicationGateway $AppGw -Name "FrontendIP02" -Subnet $Subnet

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a virtual network named VNet01 that belongs to the resource group named ResourceGroup01, and stores it in the $VNet variable.
The fourth command adds a front-end IP configuration named FrontendIP02 using $Subnet from the second command.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the goal state for a route.

Specifies the route table with which this route is associated.
Specifies the destination, in Classless Interdomain Routing (CIDR) format, to which the route applies.
Specifies how this route forwards packets. Valid values are:

-- Internet. The default Internet gateway provided by Azure. -- None. If you specify this value, the route does not forward packets. -- VirtualAppliance. A virtual appliance that you add to your Azure virtual network. -- VirtualNetworkGateway. An Azure server-to-server virtual private network gateway. -- VnetLocal. The local virtual network. If you have two subnets, 10.1.0.0/16 and 10.2.0.0/16 in the same virtual network, select a value of VnetLocal for each subnet to forward to the other subnet.

Specifies the IP address of a virtual appliance that you add to your Azure virtual network. This route forwards packets to that address. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of VirtualAppliance for the NextHopType parameter.
